discussion.content: The last words of the questions are asking for minimize the object as mush as possible, I will go for C because I will give to the IT Departement one shell profile with privilage set to 15, and then I will create different commands set that will specify the commands that the IT Group can do based on who they are

Selected Answer: C
It mentioned "The solution must minimize the number of objects created in Cisco ISE"

Selected Answer: C
This question ask before?

Selected Answer: D
Key here is want to provide different level of access, thus multiple shell profile.
If you have specific roles within your organization that require different levels of access, you can create additional shell profiles in Cisco ISE and assign them based on user attributes or group memberships.

comments.content: There is no way to achieve the required task without creating multiple shell profiles. C - minimizes the number of objects but does not complete the required task. D - addresses the task with the minimum number of objects required to satisfy the task. ie different levels of access + specific commands

Nope!. you are missing ". The solution must minimize the number of objects created in Cisco ISE" So you can solve this with 1 shell profile giving level 15 access and then command sets to handle who can do what

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
it is C, with one shell you can set various command sets.

C:
You can create 1 shell profile per device type with multiple command sets mapped to AD group. (requirement is to reduce objects D is incorrect in that case)

Selected Answer: D
Multiple shell profiles and multiple command sets.

Selected Answer: D
as refference: see Q#152
there it is mentioned that the access level has to be the same - but there the answer is "create multiple shell profiles and multiple command sets"
seems they mixed the answers...

comments.content: shell profiles are device type based, you can use same shell profile with different command set with different AD group condition.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Since we need Different Commands based on Different AD Groups, we will need Multiple shell profiles and Multiple command sets

questions.question_text: The IT manager wants to provide different levels of access to network devices when users authenticate using TACACS+. The company needs specific commands to be allowed based on the Active Directory group membership of the different roles within the IT department. The solution must minimize the number of objects created in Cisco ISE. What must be created to accomplish this task?

choices.B: multiple shell profiles and one command set
choices.A: one shell profile and one command set
choices.D: multiple shell profiles and multiple command sets
choices.C: one shell profile and multiple command sets

questions.question_text: What is the maximum number of PSN nodes supported in a medium-sized deployment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Five nodes for Cisco ISE below 3.0. 
Six nodes for Cisco ISE 3.0 above.

Selected Answer: D
Actually you can have up to 50 PSN per ISE cube

comments.content: In a large deployment you can have up to 50 PSN's, the question asks about medium size deployment. Which is 6 PSN's in ISE 3.0 and 5 PSN's for other versions.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct. in a medium size deployment the ADMIN & MNT persona are colocated on the same chassis which operationally limits the supported distributed PSN count to 5 (although I like IlPerdan0 comment, remember this is a cisco exam so expect the questions to be on ld revisions mostly!)

Selected Answer: BD
TACACS+ encrypts the full packet payload
TACACS+ uses a connection-oriented transport protocol (TCP), whereas RADIUS uses a connectionless transport protocol (UDP)

Selected Answer: BD
RADIUS uses UDP
TACACS+ use TCP
RADIUS encrypts only the password during transmission
TACACS+ encrypts the entire session
RADIUS combines authentication (device) and Authorization(User).
TACACS+ Separates Authentication, Authorization, and Accountability
RADIUS is limited in its privilege mode
TACACS+ supports15 privilege modes. In addition, you can limit router commands based on user groups.
RADIUS is an open standard and therefore more interoperable than TACACS+
TACACS+ is proprietary to cisco
RADIUS uses less memory and CPU cycles on your routers
TACACS+ is heavier than RADIUS

Selected Answer: BD
Should be B and D

choices.A: TACACS+ uses a connectionless transport protocol, whereas RADIUS uses a connection-oriented transport protocol.
choices.D: TACACS+ uses a connection-oriented transport protocol, whereas RADIUS uses a connectionless transport protocol.
choices.C: TACACS+ only encrypts the password, whereas RADIUS encrypts the full packet payload.
choices.B: TACACS+ encrypts the full packet payload, whereas RADIUS only encrypts the password.
choices.E: TACACS+ supports multiple sessions per user, whereas RADIUS supports one session per user.

questions.question_text: What are two differences of TACACS+ compared to RADIUS? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
The supported RADIUS authentication protocols are PAP, CHAP, MSCHAP, MSCHAP2, and EAP-MD5.

The supported TACACS+ authentication protocols are ASCII, PAP, CHAP, and MSCHAP.

Selected Answer: CE
EAP and MSCHAPv2 so it is correct

Provided answers are correct
https://help.stonesoft.com/onlinehelp/StoneGate/SMC/6.5.0/GUID-26D7F914-2335-4D52-BE07-869BD6D165FD.html#:~:text=The%20supported%20TACACS%2B%20authentication%20protocols,PAP%2C%20CHAP%2C%20and%20MSCHAP.

questions.question_text: Which two authentication protocols are supported by RADIUS but not by TACACS+? (Choose two.)

An engineer configured posture assessment for their network access control with the goal of using an agent that supports using service conditions for the assessment. The agent should run as a background process to avoid user interruption, but the user can see it when it is run. What is the problem?

choices.A: The selected posture agent does not support the engineer's goal.
choices.C: The proper permissions were not given to the temporal agent to conduct the assessment.
choices.B: The posture module was deployed using the headend instead of installing it with SCCM.
choices.D: The user required remediation so the agent appeared in the notifications.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Anyconnect Stealth does not support remediation that requires gui or client/manual interaction.
Temporal is not clientless.
It must be that hey deployed the wrong agent.
